title: 1. Introduction to C++
explanation: C++ is a powerful, high-performance general-purpose programming language. It was created as an extension of the C programming language and includes object-oriented features. It is widely used for developing system software, game engines, and high-performance applications.

title: 2. Basic Syntax and Structure
explanation: A C++ program consists of various components like preprocessor directives (`#include`), a `main()` function which is the entry point of the program, statements ending with a semicolon, and comments. The `iostream` library is used for input and output operations.

title: 3. Variables and Data Types
explanation: In C++, you must declare a variable's data type before you can use it. Common data types include `int` (integers), `double` (floating-point numbers), `char` (single characters), `std::string` (sequences of characters), and `bool` (true or false).

title: 4. Input and Output (cin/cout)
explanation: C++ uses streams for input and output. `std::cout` is used for output (printing to the console), and `std::cin` is used for input (reading from the console). These are part of the `iostream` library.

title: 5. Conditional Statements (if/else)
explanation: Conditional statements control the flow of execution based on a condition. The `if` statement executes a block of code if its condition is true. The `else` statement provides an alternative block of code to execute if the condition is false.

title: 6. For Loops
explanation: A `for` loop is used to repeat a block of code a specific number of times. It consists of three parts: initialization (executed once before the loop), condition (checked before each iteration), and increment/decrement (executed at the end of each iteration).

title: 7. Functions
explanation: Functions are blocks of code that perform a specific task and can be reused. You must declare a function's return type, its name, and its parameters. This helps in organizing code into manageable and modular pieces.

title: 8. Introduction to Pointers
explanation: A pointer is a variable that stores the memory address of another variable. Pointers are a powerful feature of C++ that allow for direct memory manipulation, dynamic memory allocation, and efficient handling of data structures. The `&` operator gets the address of a variable, and the `*` operator dereferences a pointer to get the value at that address.

title: 9. Introduction to Classes and Objects
explanation: A class is a blueprint for creating objects. It bundles data (attributes) and methods (functions) that work on the data into a single unit. An object is an instance of a class. This is the foundation of object-oriented programming (OOP).

title: 10. Standard Template Library (STL) - Vector
explanation: The STL is a collection of C++ template classes to provide common programming data structures and functions such as lists, stacks, arrays, etc. `std::vector` is a sequence container that encapsulates dynamic size arrays. It's like a more powerful and flexible version of a standard array.
